repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
by letting `best_match` do full validation.

Hopefully fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4539.

Currently draft because I haven't written tests - I'm just trying to see how much it breaks.

comment_data.body: Hmm. Do we need this flag? I'd rather not add a "do your job" and a "really do your job" kind of behavioural distinction. Comparing argument types doesn't seem like a bad idea in general.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4577,7 +4580,8 @@ def is_promotion(src_type, dst_type):
             return src_type.is_float and src_type.rank <= dst_type.rank
     return False
 
-def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None):
+def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None,
+               validate_types_fully=False):

comment_data.body: Shouldn't this just read `global_scope = self.global_scope()`? Without the loop?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1000,13 +1000,25 @@ def lookup_operator(self, operator, operands):
             method = obj_type.scope.lookup("operator%s" % operator)
             if method is not None:
                 arg_types = [arg.type for arg in operands[1:]]
-                res = PyrexTypes.best_match(arg_types, method.all_alternatives())
+                res = PyrexTypes.best_match(arg_types, method.all_alternatives(),
+                                            validate_types_fully=True)
                 if res is not None:
                     return res
         function = self.lookup("operator%s" % operator)
         function_alternatives = []
         if function is not None:
             function_alternatives = function.all_alternatives()
+        nonmember_alternatives = []
+        if self.is_cpp_class_scope and function and function.scope is self:
+            # for C++ classes we can have both member and non-member operators
+            # and we really want to consider both
+            outer_scope = self.outer_scope
+            while outer_scope and not outer_scope.is_module_scope:
+                outer_scope = outer_scope.module_scope

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
            # Note that the first argument is not necessarily "self"
            # (with non-member operators), so complete types
            # must be specified.
            operands = operand_types
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4048,10 +4048,13 @@ def assignable_from_resolved_type(self, other_type):
     def attributes_known(self):
         return self.scope is not None
 
-    def find_cpp_operation_type(self, operator, operand_type=None):
-        operands = [self]
-        if operand_type is not None:
-            operands.append(operand_type)
+    def find_cpp_operation_type(self, operator, operand_types=None):
+        if operand_types is not None:
+            operands = operand_types  # note that the first argument is not
+                # necessarily "self" (non-member operators) so complete types
+                # must be specified

comment_data.body: This looks funny and seems worth explaining – why continue if we only have a single candidate anyway?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4663,7 +4667,7 @@ def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None):
             candidates.append((func, func_type))
 
     # Optimize the most common case of no overloading...
-    if len(candidates) == 1:
+    if len(candidates) == 1 and not validate_types_fully:

comment_data.body: I've removed it... we'll see if everything else still works.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4577,7 +4580,8 @@ def is_promotion(src_type, dst_type):
             return src_type.is_float and src_type.rank <= dst_type.rank
     return False
 
-def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None):
+def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None,
+               validate_types_fully=False):

comment_data.body: That's gone now, but I think the answer is "because we might actually have no candidates, but just not realize it"
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4663,7 +4667,7 @@ def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None):
             candidates.append((func, func_type))
 
     # Optimize the most common case of no overloading...
-    if len(candidates) == 1:
+    if len(candidates) == 1 and not validate_types_fully:

comment_data.body: I came to the conclusion that the flag is needed unfortunately. I changed the name to `validate_types_for_operators` to make it seem a little less like "do your job" and a "really do your job".
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4577,7 +4580,8 @@ def is_promotion(src_type, dst_type):
             return src_type.is_float and src_type.rank <= dst_type.rank
     return False
 
-def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None):
+def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None,
+               validate_types_fully=False):

comment_data.body:
It still feels like it's working by accident. If things only work because of the shortcut, in cases where we have exactly one candidate, then the whole machinery that gets triggered by having two (or more) candidates starts to feel fragile.

I looked at the test results and yes, removing the shortcut breaks it pretty badly. But that suggests to me even stronger that the shortcut is a general issue. At least its position at the front. Maybe we should rather have it as a fallback in the end. And maybe keep a tighter variant in the beginning only for the one _really_, really obvious case.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4577,7 +4580,8 @@ def is_promotion(src_type, dst_type):
             return src_type.is_float and src_type.rank <= dst_type.rank
     return False
 
-def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None):
+def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None,
+               validate_types_fully=False):

comment_data.body:
I'll have another go at it in a bit - I agree it does seem very fragile.

I think the issue for the functions that broke was that they had a generic PyObject, but required a `long`. That's obviously something that we can handle (it's a conversion with an exception if a long isn't suitable), but it doesn't fit into the "pick the best C++ overload" logic. I suspect it probably should fit into the logic, but with low priority and only when there's one option.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4577,7 +4580,8 @@ def is_promotion(src_type, dst_type):
             return src_type.is_float and src_type.rank <= dst_type.rank
     return False
 
-def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None):
+def best_match(arg_types, functions, pos=None, env=None, args=None,
+               validate_types_fully=False):

commit.message:
best_match to skip single alternative shortcut

Add an option to let best-match skip single alternative shortcut,
thus validating the match fully. This is potentially useful for
operator lookup.
Make sure to evaluate full list of members/non-members
Use a single comment block (with a proper sentence) instead of lines that jump back end forth.

commit.message: Comment code a bit better, new test

Try to make `best_match` do full validation

by passing env to it so that it can check for coercible types.
Try resolving types before coercion check

title: Fix non-member operator lookup
